stories.text:
I noticed that a lot of people love "little nice things" in macOS[1] and other Apple software. Things that will not get noticed in a big splashy release. Sometimes, most users don't even notice the attention to details and work that went into making things work nicely.

I work on UIs too but in our organization nobody really cares about nice little things. It's all about launching and making a new big product or release. I have been in many big tech companies and most of them are like this. Apple is special. Somehow their culture allows obsessing over details.

If your organization is successful in rewarding craftsmanship, can you share how they do it?

[1] https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=31315644
stories.title: Ask HN: How does your organization reward polishing software?

stories.text:
1. This stuff is not webby, usually. Hash trees are not the web. IPFS is not the web. NFTs are not the web. PoW is not the web.

2. The web2 meme was hype from the beginning. Just let it die.

3. Other tech (like, RDF) already tried to claim the term “web 3,” years ago. Trying to snarf it isn't even original.

4. Aspiring to be “web 3” is euphoria. It's delusional. The web is a monster success. Almost nothing in krypto compares.

When people talk about crypto or web3 what they usually mean is P2P. Just say it if that's what you mean.
stories.title: Can we fix the term “Web3”? It is cringe
